grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

Explanations about Options.-mtime:
File's data was last modified n*24 hours ago. See the comments for -atime to
 understand how rounding affects the interpretation of file modification times.
Explanations about Options.-maxdepth:
Descend at most levels (a non-negative integer) levels of directories below the
 starting-points. -maxdepth 0 means only apply the tests and actions to the
 starting-points themselves.
Explanations about Options.-name:
This option is supported, but POSIX conformance depends on the POSIX conformance of
 the system's fnmatch(3) library function. As of findutils-4.2.2, shell
 metacharacters (`*', `?' or `[]' for example) will match a leading `.', because
 IEEE PASC interpretation 126 requires this. This is a change from previous
 versions of findutils.
Explanations about Options.-print:
Quoting is handled in the same way as for -printf and -fprintf. If you are using
 find in a script or in a situation where the matched files might have arbitrary
 names, you should consider using -print0 instead of -print.

Explanations about Options.-0:
Input items are terminated by a null character instead of by whitespace, and the
 quotes and backslash are not special (every character is taken literally).
 Disables the end of file string, which is treated like any other argument. Useful
 when input items might contain white space, quote marks, or backslashes. The GNU
 find -print0 option produces input suitable for this mode.

 experimental when combined with the -z (--null-data) option, and grep -P may warn
 of unimplemented features.

 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
Explanations about Options.-i:
Ignore case distinctions in patterns and input data, so that characters that differ
 only in case match each other.

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

Explanations about Options.-h: with -l and -s, print sizes like 1K 234M 2G etc.
Explanations about Options.-a: do not ignore entries starting with .
Explanations about Options.-d: list directories themselves, not their contents
Explanations about Options.-u:
with -lt: sort by , and show , access time; with -l: show access time and sort by
 name; otherwise: sort by access time, newest first
Explanations about Options.-c:
with -lt: sort by , and show , ctime (time of last modification of file status
 information); with -l: show ctime and sort by name; otherwise: sort by ctime,
 newest first
Explanations about Options.-n: like -l, but list numeric user and group IDs
Explanations about Options.-x: list entries by lines instead of by columns
Explanations about Options.-t: sort by modification time , newest first
Explanations about Options.-i: print the index number of each file
Explanations about Options.-m: fill width with a comma separated list of entries

grep.-n: Prefix each line of output with the 1-based line number within its input file.
grep.-w:
Select only those lines containing matches that form whole words. The test is that
 the matching substring must either be at the beginning of the line, or preceded by
 a non-word constituent character. Similarly, it must be either at the end of the
 line or followed by a non-word constituent character. Word-constituent characters
 are letters, digits, and the underscore. This option has no effect if -x is also
 specified.
grep.-r:
Read all files under each directory, recursively, following symbolic links only if
 they are on the command line. Note that if no file operand is given, grep searches
 the working directory. This is equivalent to the -d recurse option.
grep.--include:
Search only files whose base name matches GLOB (using wildcard matching as
 described under --exclude).

This command is  used  with --logdir. --logflush Clears (flushes) the log file after each write action. --logdebug Also  output  debug-level  messages  in  the log (equivalent to setting the env var QT_LOGGING_RULES="qt.*=true;*.debug=true"). ) --confdir <dirname> Uses the specified configuration directory.
